title: Expect health insurance prices to rise next year, brokers and experts say
description: Pricey prescriptions and nagging medical costs are swamping some insurers and employers now. Patients may start paying for it next year.
content:
Health insurance will grow more expensive in many corners of the market in 2026, and coverage may shrink. That could leave patients paying more for doctor visits and dealing with prescription coverage changes.

“We’re in a period of uncertainty in every health insurance market right now, which is something we haven’t seen in a very long time,” said Larry Levitt, an executive vice president at the nonprofit KFF, which studies health care.

Get the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.
• There was an error, please provide a valid email address. A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder. The next issue of Top Stories will soon be in your inbox. We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try again

Enrollment in the Affordable Care Act’s insurance marketplaces swelled the past few years. But a crackdown on fraud and a tightening of eligibility verifications that were loosened during the COVID-19 pandemic makes it harder for some to stay covered, Jefferies analyst David Windley noted.

New gene therapies that can come with a one-time cost of more than $2 million also are having an impact, insurance brokers say. Those drugs, which target rare diseases, and some newer cancer treatments are part of the reason Sun Life Financial covered 47 claims last year that cost over $3 million.

The financial services company covers high-cost claims for employers that pay their own medical bills. Sun Life probably had no claims that expensive a decade ago and maybe “a handful at best” five years ago, said Jen Collier, president of health and risk solutions.

Price hikes will be most apparent on the Affordable Care Act’s individual coverage marketplaces. Insurers there are raising premiums around 20% in 2026, according to KFF, which has been analyzing state regulatory filings.
summary: Health insurance prices are expected to increase in 2026, potentially leading to increased costs and decreased coverage. This could result in patients paying more for doctor visits and prescription coverage changes. The increase is expected to be seen in the Affordable Care Act's individual coverage marketplaces, where insurers are raising premiums by around 20% in 2025. Additionally, new gene therapies with a one-time cost of over $2 million are also contributing to this increase.
shortSummary: Health insurance prices will rise significantly in 2026, potentially leading to coverage cuts, increased costs, and prescription changes, with increases expected across various markets.

argos_summary: Health insurance premiums are projected to rise by about 20% in 2026, especially on Affordable Care Act marketplaces, as regulators tighten fraud checks and eligibility verifications. Rising costs are driven in part by expensive gene therapies and new cancer treatments, with insurers like Sun Life reporting multi-million dollar claims for rare disease drugs. The combination of higher premiums and stricter coverage rules may leave patients paying more for doctor visits and facing reduced prescription coverage.
